os_net_config/impl_nmstate.py.message: I think we can use this general approach, but I'm open to suggestion about how to do this better. I need to work on this some, it doesn't yet properly handle lists of dicts.

Oops, this comment refers to previous functionality that returned a list of dicts of all interfaces if interface wasn't supplied. I'm still waffling about whether a function that grabs all interfaces is required, or if we only need to get state on particular interfaces.

I'm not sure if it makes sense to pretty-print the JSON we are applying, I'm open to suggestion about whether a simple one-line JSON string is acceptable. It seems like a pretty-print version would mean one less step for troubleshooting, at the expense of extra space in the log.
I think I might be able to remove this method entirely, or it might still be needed as a way to determine whether we should apply routes with iproute2 vs. nmstate. TBD.

nmstate does not handle routes in the NetworkManager DB, those still get written to route-<iface> files in /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts. I need to do some testing to determine if nmstate will apply new routes in a non-impactful way, or if we should add/remove routes manually using 'ip route'. If we can do it all through nmstate, then we don't need to run ip route commands.

glance/api/v2/discovery.py.message:
Would it be possible to remove those "if" conditions and instead do:

store['properties'] = g_store.get_store_properties(store['id'])

And move all the driver-specific code inside the driver classes in glance_store? The method from the base class would return {} or raise "NotImplementedError".

I agree with what Cyril says that glance store should be handling this instead of glance but from a practical standpoint, that would increase the scope of this work a lot and also the complexity of managing this code on both glance and glance store side. Also we already have a method exposing the store object from glance store side ``get_store_from_store_identifier`` which provides us with the necessary information needed to be exposed.
So practically, I think it makes more sense to handle this here (since we have to make changes into glance anyway) and don't increase the scope of this work for very little benefit for now.

Also the approach suggested by Abhishek looks cleaner and will allow to add/remove the exposed parameters easily in future.

The idea behind using this is to avoid any change to glance-store library and use the existing available store call (get_store_from_store_identifier). But to avoid these if conditions we can surely improve it like;

https://paste.opendev.org/show/b0v367Nl5307iJQ5SrMI/

Please add comment why you are returning empty dictionary from here.
Also self parameter is not used in any of these methods so you can mark these methods as static.
We should be predictable and descriptive here: 'large_object_size'
Lets be consistent and drop the 's3_store_' prefix from the keys as the store type is not highlighted on any other drivers either.

I still think you should use the actual config option name as the key for each of these (for all stores).  Might be worth asking at the next cinder weekly meeting if anyone else shares my concern [0], I'll go along with whatever the consensus is.

[0] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/glance/+/842045/6#message-e09dac21cf2bd2f75d108f061e2e3ba7f0e8a9b7

Ack
As discussed we would be using the actual config option name as the key

See my comment below about the swift driver.  We have the same issue here, namely, chunk_size is a computed value in bytes [0], whereas an operator can only configure rbd_store_chunk_size in MB.

[0] https://opendev.org/openstack/glance_store/src/commit/befcca345b233cae28cd320f20592aaab3fa289a/glance_store/_drivers/rbd.py#L337

The problem with this one is that we've already released the rbd discovery call.  Not sure what our options are.

I said this during the meeting, but exposing this in bytes when the operator can only configure it in *multiples* of MiB is not a problem, IMHO, and I don't understand the concern.

In the 'df' example I gave, 'df' will tell you how many bytes you have total on your disk, but you can only technically add to those in 512 or 4096 byte chunks. Especially if we're trying to make things consistent between backends, exposing bytes for all of them regardless of their own alignment (or other) requirements makes total sense to me.

Looking at the glance_store code, it looks like the keys here should be (if we're going from the configuration option names):

swift_store_container
swift_store_large_object_size
swift_store_large_object_chunk_size

The large_object_size and large_object_chunk_size are computed from the options:
https://opendev.org/openstack/glance_store/src/commit/befcca345b233cae28cd320f20592aaab3fa289a/glance_store/_drivers/swift/store.py#L794-L797

I don't know which ones we should display.  The computed values are in bytes, but you can't configure a particular byte value because the config options must be expressed in MB, so I don't know that having the large_object_size is useful to an operator because they can't do anything with it (plus, the byte value is kind of weird, it uses a "mixed" meaning of MB [0].  So displaying the computed values may not be very helpful, and could be confusing.

The thing to do here might be to just pull the values out of the configuration (or I guess you could use the store_detail and reverse the computation).  (You can see that I'm leaning toward displaying the config options.)


[0] https://opendev.org/openstack/glance_store/src/commit/befcca345b233cae28cd320f20592aaab3fa289a/glance_store/_drivers/swift/store.py#L54
As discussed in the weekly meeting we are moving ahead by renaming the swift_store options at the moment and implementing it in the same way as we did before

The problem here is that, except for 'swift_store_container', the displayed values will *not* be the configured value, and it's not an obvious translation because the large object size in bytes is based on ONE_MB = units.k * units.Ki.

I think the correct thing here depends on what we decide to do about the rbd case.  If we are eventually going to display both configured *and* computed, then we should not use the config names for lines 107-108 now.

I don't understand why the translation is not obvious, because you gave the obvious translation, didn't you?

Are you saying you think whoever is consuming this API is doing so in a way that will be confusing if it's not identical to the number they put in the config file? I'm not sure what the point of the API is, if that's the case. I assumed this was for use by people other than those that wrote the actual config file so they know things about the backends in a generic way, and without needing to read the config file. If so, showing the computed/reasoned/sanitized value in a generic way makes total sense to me.

Why did you not replicate the length checking here? We should be able to know even more information about the remote image if it's a glance, and be able to ensure we at least got what we think is the whole thing.

When I brought up checking the hash of the image after we got it, Erno asserted that we can just trust the transport. If that's what we're going with, it seems like we should at least assert that we got all the data before we assume the image is fine. Right?

That's because we can't rely on the remote server to always provide content-length, and I don't even think remote glances will set it, which means we never get the check in that case right? But we *can* rely on knowing from glance via its API, right? We *should* check anything we can, IMHO, especially since we're not checking hashes.

It would be better to put his defaulting of the service interface into the API code itself. The "default of public, if unspecified" is really an API contract with the user. Putting the defaulting of it there makes it clear in the future that a change would be API-visible, and thus be breaking or require signaling.

I suspect you should catch GlanceEndpointNotFound explicitly and generate some specific failure to avoid the traceback and make it clear what the problem is.

it can just not to the same host where the inactive binding is.

s/You can't/You shouldn't

The method "create_port_binding" was created to implement the multiple port binding feature [1] and that feature had in mind live migration only. We should have created the DB table "ml2_port_bindings" with a limitation on (port,status), being unable to have more than one port in inactive or active status.

[1]https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1580880

i have seen the port bindihng not get deleted because nova asked neutron to delete it and that failed internally in neutron at the db level.
i think this was related to segmented network tempest tests in some way but its been a while.

i have also see duplicates created because nova tried to delete the port binding and that times out.


im also pretty sure you can have more then 2 port bidnigns.
i have defintly seen ports in the past that have more then 1 inactive port binding where all 3 ports has a differnt host id
if that is not possibel anymore its a cange in behavior from what i recall.

What "internal db issue"? This is quite generic. I've seen this error caused because Nova didn't attend to the vif-plugged event, libvirt issues, RPC issues, etc.

Not really. "PortBinding.get_duplicated_port_bindings" will return a list of "port_id" of those duplicated port bindings. That means I'll get only one "port_id" from two port binding registers. Please check that in this method I'm grouping the results; that means I'll have only one port_id only.

We also need to check the acceptor path, in case the acceptor that is overlapped is new (in the case where we may perhaps have a parent and children shard, we don't know if the parent or the recently-created children are in the acceptor path vs the donors).

Fortunately we have a ShardRange.overlaps method, so if we iterate over the acceptor path we can check if each acceptor.overlaps(donor) for all donors, and if it does then check its age.

this is ok, but worth noting that ShardRange.__hash__ is based (unusually) on the object id (i.e. each instance will hash differently) rather than the "value" of the object [1], so we need to be careful using sets because two ShardRanges with the same name, timestamp, upper and lower could both end up in the set. It is OK here because the set is only populated from qualified_donors which is already a set of unique ShardRanges.

  s1 = u.ShardRange('a/c', 123, 'l', 'u')
  s2 = u.ShardRange('a/c', 123, 'l', 'u')
  len(set([s1, s2]))
  2
  
  [1] https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/2d063cd61f6915579840a41ac0248a26085e0245/swift/common/utils.py#L5645-L5649
Yes, I assumed ShardRange.__hash__ is based on content. But unique ShardRange and id worked in this case, thanks for pointing it out.

OK, so we can get here from repair or analyze -- are we sure we want them to give different answers like this? Would it be better for analyze to also grow the new option?
Done

OIC, I hadn't fully appreciated that analyze also ended up here - I thought the condition was just defensive coding.

I think it would be better for analyze to either:

1) hard code args.min_shard_age = 0 so that this code path is ok without the guard condition

or

2) fully support the command line option same as repair

The reason I'm wondering about option 1 is whether the semantic of 'analyze' should be 'tell me everything of interest about these shard ranges'[1] (therefore no default filtering) vs 'repair' being 'guide me to sensible modifications'.

I'd prefer us not to spend time supporting the command line option for 'analyze' but with a *different* default, given how little use analyze gets in my experience.


[1] of course, right now 'analyze' does not tell us much because it hasn't been developed much e.g. it does not report gaps.

I'm happy with this. I discussed with JianJian and my feeling is that for the analyze command (vs repair) it is not appropriate to filter out overlaps based on age *by default* so the default of 0 here makes sense.
Done

tobiko/openstack/ovsdb/_nbdb.py.message: These are creating connection and closing them every time we call these methods that is quite expensive I think. We should instead cached connections in a manager and use tobiko.setup_fixture method on them just in time when we need them.

This is going to create a new connection every time we call this function and it will never close it. In fact the reference to api value is being lost and with it the whole connection. 

Please implement a connection manager to solve it.

For example the requests library has a nice concept called connection pool (the same as a manager). When you ask for a connection it creates it, it makes the request an then it restore it to a pool for later reuse.

An alternative approach could be how tobiko SSH client or openstack clients work.

If _lient.DBAPI is a fixture, then we should do as below:

 tobiko.setup_fixture(self)

tobiko/openstack/ovsdb/_ovsdb.py.message: Connection should be kept by a manager and reused for more than one method call.

I think ssh client proxy stuff should be implemented in the _client module for API classes. Port forwarding is an expensive resource. This is why we should cache API instances in a connection manager so we reuse the same API to the same database instance.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: checksums, it is plural, you're doing more than one.

I need a much better description here.  Why are these checksums now broken?  Have we been checking them but only warning if they mismatch?  How do we know that the checksumming isn't doing its job right now and warning that some packages have been compromised?

I only check with the original developer of openldap why the checksum is incorrect. It is probably the openldap tar.gz has been changed after e1f6fe0d, or the developer set a wrong checksum originally.

The downloader doesn't do checksum after downloading a file. We capture the return value of "wget" to determine if the download is succeed. It only does checksum when rerun downloader to avoid redownloading. If a package is with a wrong checksum, it doesn't impact the first download, and always redownload, not error is reported.

We plan to add checksum after download because we observed a file is 0 size with wget return 0. Before adding it, we need to correct the wrong checksum.

OK, so currently the checksums are not being checked, but that will be enforced soon?  The only reason we added 256sums is for security purposes, as md5sum is perfectly good for just verifying download integrity, but it is not secure.  A bad actor can change a package and still have it produce the same md5sum, but not 256sum.

State in the header here:

"Checksums are currently not being checked upon download.  This commit corrects them with the intent for us to turn on checking soon.  Various reasons exist for these checksums not being correct, the main one being developers moving the package forward and forgetting to update the checksums."
This task only refers to openldap.  Have you decided to correct all packages that the downloader has an issue with?  If so, state that.

exist for these checksums

It doesn't look like you directly copied and pasted from my comment.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Is this a bug? Or better: shouldn't we use tempest/master from victoria and wallaby? So why is there an incompatibility?
Isn't the manila-tempest-plugin pinning applied to devstack jobs? Or maybe I'm mixing up the fixes

I'm not sure we need to fix this globally in whole CI for everyone as no one is experiencing any issues (I presume, I haven't seen any communication stating otherwise) .. so, from my point of view, it is quite simple, if we want to run manila tests in our jobs we need to either use newer tempest or downgrade the plugin due to this change: https://opendev.org/openstack/manila-tempest-plugin/commit/0e4a3d2a877c4e85d73e3f3a318c5dfaa4624a27

it is, it's to avoid this issue in a devstack job during deployment when devstack installs all things together:
https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/e2f38826ed3747338679b3ca56a4dbe9

the pin is just for the CI jobs, it doesn't affect python-tempestconf which isn't dependent on manila-tempest-plugin anyhow

I'm a bit confused but if I understand it correctly, we do have tempest in upper-constraints.txt, and that affects the installation of the manila devstack plugin when it installs manila-tempest-plugin.

Now I wonder
- whether the manila devstack plugin should really install manila-tempest-plugin and that should be handled directly by the specific tempest playbooks; that would solve the issue.
- given the special rules for tempest, whether it makes sense to pin in in upper-constraints; it should be pinned after tagging the <version>-last tag IMHO

currently we use a default tempest version for a given release (most likely based on RDO) so therefore the conflict exists.

yes, there are 2 options how to deal with this, first one is to use master tempest everywhere, the other is to "alter" plugin's version on old releases.

As RDO controls versions of tempest and python-tempestconf we let to be available for a certain release, I think it makes sense to test with tempest which is available for that release (not master).

General comment.  When I started reviewing first this had a look and feel of a generic agent for NVMe and not specific to Kumoscale.  is this new connection agent exclusive to Kumoscale, it's difficult to tell

This is a good find, thank you! This likely got overlooked, I will change the message to be more proper (because this format is not specific to KumoScale, it is the same connection_properties format that is used by the NVMeOF connector replicated mode, this format is implemented by the KumoScale driver, but it can also be implemented by other drivers as well)

To more fully answer your question, a current best attempt was made to make this agent as generic as possible, yet there are likely more changes needed to fully abstract out the vendor-specific bits (this was mentioned at the PTG, a best effort making sure the core non-vendor related nvmeof operations are all generic - but, there is still a lot of wiggle room in provisioner communication, so it is not perfect. As other vendors decide to implement drivers that use replicated nvmeof connector and this agent, the potentially still missing pieces of the vendor-abstraction will surface and then be addressed)

Do we need both conditions.  
if targets is None should mean its empty and len == 0.  These little things always get me.

In general such similar little things get to me too and I get nitty on those with the team as well (you should see our inner workings 😊)

But, in this case, I think that len(None) throws an exception, that is why this one actually makes sense.

>>> nonevar = None
>>> len(nonevar)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>

maybe check to see if nvme_live_legs is not None in case it is None and throws a 
TypeError: object of type 'NoneType' has no len()

That truely makes sense to be safe, and it would be 100% necessary if there was a code path that could lead to it being None.

I did take a look and traced it back: handle_leg_failure() assigns [] to the nvme_live_legs that it returns and only appends to it, so im pretty sure with current code it will never be None.

I would change it to be safe, but there are many other similar occurnces of len() being used on a variable without checking if it is None, so for the above reasons and to minimize code agitation, I rather keep this one the way it is.

Since this is a generic agent, you should make the provisioner_entities and provisioner_rest_client configurable in the conf file, and then use importutils from oslo.utils to import the classes.  (You can look at cinder for an example, I think the backup manager does a lot of this.)

Thank you, good point and great suggestion, this is a good initial approach for making the agent generic.

With this, it is already modular enough for any other "agent driver" implementations using custom rest_api and entitie.

However, just to mention here for completion, there could still some work to be done abstracting out driver-specific methods, such that logic can be changed (or omitted) by other drivers, other than just implementing their own copy of the provisioner rest api. This will be added in a followup over time, based on new drivers (or changes in current driver) needs.

you can't really do this ... this agent class shouldn't have any knowledge of the internals of the rest client module

(see https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/os-brick/+/804813 for a different way to handle this)
Ack
resolving this using a vendor-specific "agent driver" class

I know this is kind of ugly, but I'm not sure how else we can do this.  Cinder has a script that crawls all the drivers and generates a python file, but I think that's overkill until we reach the point of there being more than 4 or so agent implementations.

I also thought this is kinda ugly, so I did look around for how it's done in other services, specifically Cinder.

I found https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/src/branch/master/cinder/opts.py
Which essentially does the same thing as here; it imports every driver one by one (not even automatically, they are all explicitly "hardcoded" in) - and adds each driver's custom opts to the output of list_opts()

For this reason, I found that this is fully consistent with the way Cinder already does it, so I think it should be done this way here too (at least until this whole opts importing and listing approach, including on the Cinder side, is revisited)

os_brick/cmd/nvmeof_agent/rest_client.py.message: If this is exclusive to Kioxia, should it be more apparent in the directory structure or file name?
Great point, thank you! Addressing in patchset 4.
Perhaps this comment should be a docstring? Comment for methods below too.
In general I agree and I could go through and make these comment changes, but I have some reasons outlined for why I prefer to keep it the way it is for now in my response on line 378

"""Call to Get Info API

:returns: Provisioner response data contain Provisioner information
"""

Suggestion only.  There may be a reason you have it this way

This is the standard that our dev team uses, it is not always kept, or kept in the best form, but it is so far the best effort.

Another thing about this rest_client is that it is Kioxia KumoScale specific, and it appears in the same way in the Cinder repo - in KumoScale cinder driver.

For this reason I rather keep it the same, to avoid divergence (which will be less confusing for KumoScale team, since this is code that is only specific to Kioxia KumoScale anyway)

For this os-brick nvmeof connection agent, this KumoScale rest_client is the first "agent driver" (other vendors would need to add and maintain their own equivalent)

Finally, we are not the happiest with the duplication of this rest_client (which is now being used both by cinder driver and os-brick agent) - and although this is the current approach, we are looking into solutions of a way to package it as a dependency (that is also "openstack certified") for both brick and cinder. Once that is figured out and done, this code should be taken out from here.

Hopefully this is a good overview of what's going on in this file!

src/actions.yaml.message: While iff is quite clear, I do think its reasonable that we spell this out for non-native-english speakers or use different phrasing. It may be interpreted as 'if' rather than the more ominous "if and only if".

src/actions/actions.py.message: What happens to the other existing units? What does a user do with those?
Yep, that's what is meant by "If and only if quorum is permanently lost", but I can see how that may not be clear enough.
Existing units should be removed.  I'll add that info there, good catch.
Ah well, then we should definitely mention that kind of thing in the documentation about the action. "This is a last resort when all hope is lost" kind of thing.

Hmm, I'll think about this a bit. The unit that is chosen to bootstrap the cluster *may* not be the juju leader unit in this scenario, which kind of complicates things a bit. Manual recovery is fine for a first pass, but it would be nice to be able to not have to remove units if they can be restored.

> The unit that is chosen to bootstrap the cluster *may* not be the juju leader unit in this scenario, which kind of complicates things a bit. 

How so?

> Manual recovery is fine for a first pass, but it would be nice to be able to not have to remove units if they can be restored.

By the way, for context this recovery action is supposed to be a last resort - only if enough instances are _permanently_ lost such that quorum is lost.

If some units are down/unreachable/lost, the quorum will be restored automatically once they are back up.

The expected path where this action fits is:

- oh no N units are broken and quorum is lost
- *investigates broken units*
- these units are broken beyond repair, so we need to scrap them
- remove the broken units
- stop all but one of the working units (ie. to keep them around in case some disaster happens to the one you've chosen to bootstrap)
- run this action on the last running unit
- confirm it's working
- add new units until the cluster is the desired size
- remove the rest of the old stopped units.
This should probably be a const?
Hmm it's not used anywhere else, so maybe better to keep it in one place?
Does this action preserve the Vault's data? It would be great to have a functional test to prove that data is preserved when force-bootstrapping

Yes it does preserve the data; it's the standard upstream process documented at https://learn.hashicorp.com/tutorials/vault/raft-lost-quorum .

Can a functional test targeting this come later in the interests of not further delaying this patch?
Rather than dumping YAML into the `output` key, could we just `action_set(state)` which would give us structured data in the output of the action?

Unfortunately not, because it appears there are constraints on the keys (lowercase alphanumeric, hyphens, and periods only) and values (coerced to strings).  Thoughts?  Ok to leave as is and wait for feedback from users about how they want to use this action?

src/config.yaml.message:
This won't work for just any path as the snap [0] doesn't have permissions to read/write very many other locations. It has access to non-hidden files in the home directory, but this would probably also need to add the removable-media plug so it can read/write volumes in /mnt [1]. It will also need to spelled out which paths would work, otherwise vault will get denied access to the configured storage path here.

[0] https://git.launchpad.net/snap-vault/tree/snap/snapcraft.yaml
[1] https://snapcraft.io/docs/removable-media-interface

100% agree with you @Nobuto - I don't think this needs to be configurable. I can see a scenario where someone would want to add it to more permanent (or larger/faster/encrypted (make it doubly encrypted?) storage) which I think can be abstracted away just by allowing the option of juju storage. It is unnecessary for initial implementation however.

> Does this have to be configurable in the first place?

Good point.  I assumed yes because I can think of two scenarios:

- storing on the local filesystem which is the default
- storing on a separate path if the data needs to be on an attached and mounted larger external device

My assumption could be false; what do you think?

Vault HA assumes 3 units, which means 3 replicas of raft based database. So it doesn't make much sense to use an external storage to me. If there is an absolute necessity, users can mount a storage onto the predefined path instead of using a custom and arbitrary path.
Does this have to be configurable in the first place? I think we can be opinionated here not to allow a customized path..

So it would require an update to the snap as well in order to allow it to have access the removable media devices (there may be a better interface - there's a few for storage/filesystem access). Instead of having this as a config option, I'd suggest tying this to Juju storage [0]. It makes it simpler as the deployer can determine the type of storage to provide, but the charm gets to determine where it should go. As such, the check would simply be whether storage is attached or not for the local raft data store.

[0] - https://juju.is/docs/sdk/storage

Ok that makes sense.

> also need to add the removable-media plug so it can read/write volumes in /mnt

Is this a modification that must be done on the snap, or a config that can be done when installing the snap from the charm?

src/lib/charm/vault.py.message: added the retry because it can take a little time before this endpoint is available while the raft cluster settles to begin with.

src/reactive/vault_handlers.py.message:
this seems in contrary to the reactive charm docs: https://charmsreactive.readthedocs.io/en/latest/charms.reactive.decorators.html

But yes comment reflects what I experienced in testing.

I think this can be simplified with:

```
if not any_flag_set('db.master.available', 'shared-db.available',
                    'etcd.tls.available'):
```
Rather than removing the storage check, it should probably add a third check for something like raft.cluster.joined

I'm hesitant to do this, because these conditions are pretty pointless (db*.available doesn't imply that vault is even initialised yet), all tests still pass with this removed, and I couldn't find an original reason for the conditions to be used in the first place.

I think that there's a lot of risk of initialising Vault with a Raft cluster because this happens before the database relation is fully configured. What happens when we later add the shared-db or db.master?

It's not that risky - the worst that will happen is that there will be an unused initialised raft config/db sitting in the filesystem.  If a shared-db or db.master is added later, vault will be reconfigured to use that and restarted.  It will retain no connection to whatever previous db/config being used.

Same thing if a db.master is added, then removed, then a shared-db added.

When the conditions are satisfied (when_none, when_all), this function will be called on every hook execution. I think that we should add in another flag to cover the state where the Raft cluster has already been joined

Basically, every relation hook, install, update-status, config-changed, etc.  Any time a reactive charm runs a hook, every single function is evaluated (that has a @when type decorator) and sees if it should run.  e.g. this would run during 'update-status' as well.  It's a pain, but that's how reactive is written!

Can you define "every hook execution"?  This is something I was wondering about but couldn't find reliable docs for.  I was under the impression that a hook would be called the first time all the "when" conditions matched, but not again after unless the conditions changed, and then changed back to match again.  Is there some kind of 'clock tick' where all hooks that match are run?

> another flag to cover the state where the Raft cluster has already been joined

This also isn't as simple as it sounds I think, because we need to account for a single node vault with the raft backend too, and the possibility of adding more nodes to a single-node vault with raft.  This auto-init raft method makes this all really easy.

Ok that's good to know.

I'm a little worried about only running this method once though - it's difficult to predict exactly when this will run, and if it runs too soon, then some nodes are going to miss out joined the cluster.  I feel like we can err on the safe side here, especially since this join method appears to be idempotent.

That said, it is a waste of resources running this all the time.  Is there a combination of flags we can check to ensure this is run as early as possible, but not until all existing other units have vault running?
Is this now dead code? If I'm reading the above correctly, `_missing_interfaces` and `_incomplete_interfaces` will always be empty lists.

`and not` - it's a hidden boolean combinator using chained ifs.  Demorgan's would simplify this to:

    if not(a or b):

Are these just the packages that were installed via hooks/install? If so, they're only used for the charm itself, and should now be installed via the requirements.txt. If they're actually dependencies of Ceph, they should already be installed in the hooks.install handler.

Done
What are we storing `is_started` here for?

I'm fairly positive that the 'is_started' variable is not a magic value that causes the operator framework to move the charm into the active state. Rather, this is used in examples and example documentation. I do believe that the storing of too much state will lead to a cache coherency problem if not used carefully. While not for this patch, if this has no special meaning for this charm then we should remove it until there is defined meaning and need for it, and we should only do so when it is determined that the state is required.
This is a standard idiom in operator framework charms. I believe it's needed to let hooks now that the charm is in active state.

Just to share the research I did about this after my previous comment, is_started is used by ops_openstack: https://github.com/openstack/charm-ops-openstack/blob/66ad9918f645ec1c7e3ef502dc53da00b2505e10/ops_openstack/core.py#L185, when it's not there, the charm will always be in a waiting state
can we not install this into the virtualenv? I'm somewhat surprised that we can access the system installed python packages!
Yep, we can access them just fine. Taking a look at this, though, it appears apt is no longer a requirement, so I'm removing it.
Why are we removing this relation?
Just a leftover from when I was going to implement relations in this patchset. It can be reverted.

doc/source/aws.rst.message:
In openstack land this is typically an attribute of the instance flavor then the image will growroot into the resulting disk. As a user that makes more sense to me since you might boot an image with different sizes of disk for different needs.

Is it possible to express it that way in AWS too? Otherwise AWS users might need to upload the same image multiple times to get different sizes of disks.

As best as I can tell, this is used as a sort of "default", and then when users launch an instance, they can specify a larger disk and growroot as you describe.  Nodepool lets us set that for labels: https://zuul-ci.org/docs/nodepool/latest/aws.html#attr-providers.[aws].pools.labels.volume-size

So given all that, I think a typical user would want to just ignore this value (and so nodepool will just use the image size) and then specify a value for the label.  But maybe if they always want to use a 200G disk with a given image, maybe they set it here and ignore the label attribute.

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_cephadm/ta.message:
on L27 we **always** mount the host config dir in /etc/ceph within the container and the latter is always used to resolve the ceph related files within the container run by podman, which means that relying on {{ tripleo_cephadm_conf }}, which points to {{ tripleo_cephadm_config_home }} is wrong.

Same story when we try to select the keyring within the container.

we need to make sure this task is executed on the nfs[0] node, and not on the undercloud in case this task is run in a standalone way (which means out of the cephadm.yaml playbook context).

Same story on L59 and L78

In the logic described by this block we can:

1. extract  the key from the ceph cluster (internal use case)
2. slurp the manila key from controller node (external use case)

It turned out that we can't "register" the same variable on both task, because in the regular use case, when the key is extracted with the ansible module (internal use case) and the slurp section is skipped on L65, the "_rgw_keys" has the content of the skipped task (None), resulting in a failure during the distribution to the overcloud nodes.
To solve this problem, I just added a suffix to make sure we are able to clearly understand which variable we expect to have the right content.
This doesn't change the logic, but it's needed by the ansible design.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
> Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1
> 
> The index for configuration objects is https://zuul-ci.org/docs/zuul/latest/project-config.html

I saw that, however, I ended up on https://zuul-ci.org/docs/zuul/latest/config/job.html and was surprised when I could navigate up a level and find a list of all config object docs. You'll note that I actually provided a link to the project-config document in the new doc and this new doc is really only a pretty directory listing. Perhaps you'd rather I moved '/project-config' to '/config/index'?

By "navigate up" you mean by editing the URL?  Or is there some navigation link that we have that is broken?  Because I can't seem to find a way to get to a directory listing by clicking links in the job.html page.

I'm not particularly concerned with providing index pages for directories that aren't accessible by hyperlink from within our docs, so I think the costs of making changes to this outweigh the benefits.

You might ask "Why isn't job-config.html config/index.html?"  The answer is that configuring jobs is just one small part of configuring Zuul, and config/index.html is a bit of a misnomer.  Perhaps it should have been job-config/index.html.

If this really bothers you and you would still like to change it, then here are my thoughts:

We should not create another page which appears to be a summary of project configuration because it may be confused with the existing one which provides important context.

Here are some alternatives:

1) Move project-config down a level as you suggest.  Be sure to update the redirect map in zuul/zuul-website (that should be a second change that depends-on this one and we should merge them simultaneously).

2) Like #1 except also rename the config/ directory to job-config/.  That's probably what should have been done originally.  This needs a few more redirects in zuul-website.

3) Just add a redirect from config/$ to project-config.html in zuul-website.

4) Update this change so that config/index.html is a one liner that says "See project-config".

I still don't really like #4 and would prefer #1 or #2, or #3.

specs/yoga/ovs_agent_ext_ra.rst.message: I considered that each router will run a radvd process, sounds more precisely？

Technically it doesn't send an RA to each VM, it multicasts it onto the subnet, which causes it to reach all the VMs. Maybe something like:

"... multicast a RA on the subnet from the router interface, reaching all attached VMs."
Removed, IMO, there is a "such work" ahead.
Thses means the works at line 45-48.
I should use "packet-out", it is a common "verb" for SDN conntroller to send packet out.

I mentioned it in the RFE as well, but it needs to be covered here. In addition to sending periodic RAs, radvd also listens and responds to Router Solicitations. Failure to do that will make this "different", and delay possible configuration of an IPv6 address on a VM up to the max advert interval time.
Sure, if RS will be sent from VM to gateway, IMO, this will be "packet-in" to the controller. ovs-agent will reponse this. I will update here.
This sounds like it is the proposed change, maybe use present tense?

specs/zed/ovs_agent_ext_ra.rst.message: for now subnets aren't send to the neutron-ovs-agent at all. Will You need to send info about them to the ovs agent?
In the view of ovs-agent, it is a "pull" action, every information will be retrieved by "resource cache" related RPC. No extra works to send informations to ovs agent.
what about ports which are in the isolated networks and not connected to any router? Why You want to send RA to such ports?

Actually, you just point a defect or bug of current RA mechanism. If a subnet does not connect to a router, no radvd answer the RS request, no RA back. VMs under isolated networks will get failed to find out how to do with IPv6 address, how to configure IPv6 address, how to do with DHCPv6. So why VMs under isolated networks must get failed to work with IPv6? IMO, it should work.

So, this agent extension will make isolated networks can work for IPv6. VM under it will get RA about the IPv6 subnets prefixes, autonomous flag, managed flag and address configration flag and so on. Things are going to work then. 😊
Would you please add this to the spec?

We already have jobs for distributed DHCP (https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin/src/branch/master/zuul.d/project.yaml#L21-L22) so perhaps we can use the same or similar jobs to verify in an end-to-end environment RA also with OVS.
Note: those jobs are experimental currently

I'm not really sure I agree with that. Logically for me, and the same thing is even written in the RFE 4861: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc4861#section-4.2 RA packets should be send by router. So I'm not really sure we should go that way and be able to send RA in the isolated networks.

Basically we have 3 cases here IIUC:
1. tenant network with IPv6 subnet connected to the neutron router - that would be fine to have RA packets sending periodically to the VMs,
2. provider network not connected to the neutron router - in this case vms could get RA packets from some external routers if that's needed,
3. Isolated neutron network with IPv6 subnet - this is the case which bothers me and IMO in such case user should use DHCPv6 if it's needed. RA shouldn't IMO be send in such case.

But I'm not the best IPv6 expert for sure and I think that would be good if Brian could look into it.

@Oleg, IMO, we should document this well, users should not use these two at same time. Otherwise, we can implement this extension a bit more straight. Using the MAC and LLA of the physical router to send RA out by this extension.

The case of an external router is handled by the ipv6_ra_mode option, if it is not set, Neutron should not generate RAs, that should also be respected if this spec gets implemented.

Regarding an isolated router being too heavy, maybe then it could be a target to improve the implementation of it? like possibly replacing using radvd with something similar to what you are proposing here?

DHCPv6 also needs RAs. But I agree with the concept that only routers should send RAs. For isolated networks, why can't people add an isolated router to them if they want autoconfiguration for their interfaces?

Sure, we should make things better.

For some operating systems, if no RA send to guest VM, it will have no way to get the informations (flags inside the RA packets) about how to do with IPv6 address and other IPv6 configs (routes, gateway, DNS). The VM operating system will be hardly to determine whether the IPv6 address is configured by SLAAC or responsed by DHCPv6. VMs under isolated networks will get failed to find out how to do with IPv6 address, how to configure IPv6 address, how to do with DHCPv6 and how to do with the other config of IPv6. Because if no RA back for the RS, those operating systems will stop entire IPv6 configurations.
What about case 2 in Slawek's original comment: if RAs are sent by some external router on a provider net won't there be a conflict if we enable this new ovs agent extension?

Make sense, I will update the rule of ipv6_ra_mode option.

The main purpose is to save the external processes for routers, aka radvd will not be spawned again.

This is what I tested. The "AddLSwitchPortCommand.run_idl" returns "self.result = port.uuid". This is what I'm getting in the lookup call. I can't use lookup here, or if I use it, I need to retrieve the row with another DB call.

Good to read that lookup() accepts cmd.BaseCommand too. Something new learned today.

I've tried this but the problem is that lookup(), in the case of using a cmd.BaseCommand, returns the UUID only, not the row (record.result is the UUID). I need then to retrieve the row again using this UUID. I need the row to set/unset the "options" values.

This is why I need to use "row_by_value" and retrieve the row in one shoot.

In the BaseCommand case, it returns whatever the result of the Command is. In this case it wasn't actually a UUID, it was a Row object because what is passed to it if lsp=None is the output of lsp_get().execute() which returns a Row object. lookup() can't search by Row (though perhaps we could add that in the future). All that you need to do is to set lsp=lsp_get.execute().uuid and pass that in _update_lsp_qos_options. Then:

reference/emerging-technology-and-inacti.message: suggestion: "projects that are not so active anymore"

Hmm, maybe I'm missing something here. Are you saying we'd never release a project as "inactive"? What it sounds like here is that we would mark them as inactive at the beginning of the cycle and if they haven't fixed things by the release, we drop them to retired. Is that the intent?

I had assumed this was our way of providing one or two releases of an inactive project (marked as such) where we're just honest with consumers about the lack of activity (and potential quality) before we fully retired. This off-ramp would provide time for someone to put together a new contribution strategy (which can take months for approval) as well as to find alternatives or execute an exit strategy if nobody ever shows up.

I guess my point is, I'm not sure the point of marking a project as "inactive" internally really matters if it's not released with such a designation.

Intention here was that project enters that "inactive" state when:

    are not able to do the mandatory activities, such as release, fix testing, review incoming code, etc.

So IMHO that implies that we shouldn't make release of such project if it has e.g. broken CI and there is nobody who wants to fix it. We want to avoid the case as we had in last cycle that we had to force merge some fixes in some projects which had broken CI just before release.

I think the within one cycle time frame is too short. An inactive project usually comes to our attention as such during the elections period (when no one volunteers) or when there are problems with the release/jobs. Realistically, that is too close to release for anyone to be able to accomplish anything, even if they notice the precarious situation of the project. Which they won't, and I bet most people will only realize what happened when the project is dropped and not release for that cycle.

I agree with Dan and suggest that this label would only provide value if we allow for 2 cycles. In the meanwhile the "inactive" label which the project would be released with would provide the visibility for people who depend on it to talk to their bosses and come up with a strategy.

I just think it's too aggressive to give warning at the beginning of a cycle and retire before the end.

Can we just avoid releasing those projects for a cycle or two, then retire them to signal "okay we're done releasing for sure" ?

sure, We can give two cycles can be the criteria and we avoid releasing them. But I think during the next cycle leader assignment we might end up retiring them.

but keeping two months as criteria here is fine.

I like this idea in general, although I'm a tad worried about the term "tech preview'. In my experience, that term means effectively "beta" and the assumption is that the feature in tech preview becomes a supported feature in a subsequent release. Based on the situation we're trying to handle here, I think that might be too presumptive, meaning some projects may enter as tech preview, and never really get enough steam to become non-preview things.

What about some term with the word "Emerging" in it? Like "Emerging Technology" or something like that.

Moving backwards from "A full project" to "tech preview" is strange, since it's not a "preview" if you already had that project fully supported and the only reason it is now a "preview" is because it *hasn't* gotten any new stuff in a while :)

"Emerging" doesn't work for those things either, granted, but maybe we just need two names or something.

- less incoming changes so not merging things there does not mean that are in-active

For both the new and old projects described here, what is the "...or else" part? If you're new and you're TP for two cycles and don't make it, what happens? Straight to retired? Dropped like you never existed?

For the existing projects, it seems like a very strange progression to go "Fully Supported" -> "Preview" -> "Retired" ... to me, anyway.

Duplicate entries : 

Reply from author (similar question here https://forums.percona.com/t/proxysql-reporting-warnings-about-duplicate-keys/5720 ) : 

Hi.
The errors you see are the errors that are coming from MySQL Server when executing a query. That is, the error “Duplicate entry ‘0daea772-d11a-40a3-9dbc-4f8dafd5e77c’ for key ‘PRIMARY’” is exactly the error message that MySQL Server has sent to ProxySQL, and that ProxySQL has sent back to the application.
That also means that, if in the application you have some sort of logging and error handling, the application should know what query has triggered that error.

ProxySQL verbosity can be enhanced adding also the schemaname, but not the tablename: ProxySQL knows to which schema is connected, but doesn’t know against which table an error is generate. Also, performing the parsing of the query to get the tablename doesn’t make sense, because an error like “duplicate entry” could be generated by a simple insert/update, or triggers, stored procedure, foreign key constraints, etc.
There are two feature requests to enhance logging:
https://github.com/sysown/proxysql/issues/1059 9
https://github.com/sysown/proxysql/issues/1060 6

Finally, to answer “why ProxySQL would be issuing warnings about duplicate key entries, when there aren’t?”
Duplicate key entries do not exists because MySQL Server rejected the DML that was trying to to create a duplicate key entry.
For example, if there was already a primary key with value ‘0daea772-d11a-40a3-9dbc-4f8dafd5e77c’ and ProxySQL tried to execute an INSERT using the same PK, MySQL Server will reject the INSERT returning an error, error number 1062, error message “Duplicate entry ‘0daea772-d11a-40a3-9dbc-4f8dafd5e77c’ for key ‘PRIMARY’” . At this point, ProxySQL will generate a log entry reporting that it got an error from MySQL Server:
2017-07-06 05:44:15 MySQL_Session.cpp:2667:handler(): [WARNING] Error during query on (0,192.168.40.28,3306): 1062, Duplicate entry ‘0daea772-d11a-40a3-9dbc-4f8dafd5e77c’ for key ‘PRIMARY’

I hope this answers your questions.
Thanks

tests/unit/test_gerrit.py.message: Is this line redundant with line 902?
I think so.  I think we could remove this line, but it's harmless.
Does it make sense to hold the lock for all the approvals so that we can see each of them is queried once and then the jobs run?
I'm not sure I follow this question, can you elaborate?

The first batch of approvals added is 3 events that result in 2 queries, which verifies this change is working as expected.  You're right that the lock isn't needed for the second batch of approvals since it's a batch size of one.  But I do think we want to verify the query count before that to make sure it isn't 3 (as it would have been before this change).  I'll add comments to explain the query count.

To clarify I mean instead of holding the lock in two locations  (line 899 and then line 907) with assertions between them, do we (also) need to do a single hold of the lock that allows all the changes to enqueue together at once and then assert the changes are queried once?

In particular I think after the first set of assertions (line 906) nothing has entered the gate pipeline yet because the parent change is not approved. We then approve the parent change with the lock, but that is a single event so the lock isn't doing much? We then assert the number of queries which seems higher than expected (2 new queries for A and 1 new query for B).

zuul/driver/gerrit/gerritconnection.py.message:
I think this does introduce a subtle behavior difference. For certain events if the change had updated after the event we would have processed the change in an updated fashion. But now we'll process the previous version.

I think this is actually more correct this way. But do we need to make note of that?
I agree.  I don't think we've described this behavior in detail in the docs, so I'm not sure it warrants a release note (especially since we're making things more "technically correct").

/COMMIT_MSG.message: The nodepool change that makes use of this doesn't appear to set a DIB_BLOCK_DEVICE_CONFIG. Is this comment accurate?

Right, it just uses the default block-device config.  If we wanted to change the root disk without this change in dib, we'd have to specify the entire block-device config in nodepool and override the default -- we can't just merge in a root-disk override that way.

The --root-disk command flag is the only way to do this override currently; and this provides a way to do that same thing via environment flag.

Does that make sense?  I agree it's a very tortured path getting this set!

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/boots.message: It appears etc_hosts isn't referenced elsewhere?
This is the file created by 'backup: yes' from 'Remove existing /etc/hosts (with backup)
this is etc_hosts.backup_file, will load the latest patchset now
This task doesn't seem to be a remove operation ...

It's not. It recreates the file from the content below, saving the older file as a backup. The whole problem here (see bug) is that any command on the server will take around 45s to finish if there is no /etc/hosts with the minimum contents (setting localhost and controller-0|controller-1 hosts), and this blows the timeout for some commands (including the tar -x on restore).
In this case, probably update the task name, because "Remove" is not accurately describe the task.
